refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: The functions sg_get_network_iface_stats() and sg_get_network_iface_stats_r() return statistics about the network interfaces in the machine. Specifically, they return the speed of the interface, the duplex state, and whether it is currently up. Both functions take an optional entries parameter, which points (when given) to a size_t to take the amount of resulted vector entries.
The sg_network_iface_stats vectors got from sg_get_network_iface_stats_r() must be freed using sg_free_network_iface_stats() when not needed anymore. The caller is responsible to do it.

refsect1.title: Return Values
refsect1.para: The sg_get_network_iface_stats returns a pointer to a structure of type sg_network_iface_stats.
Note: The SG_IFACE_DUPLEX_UNKNOWN value could mean that duplex hasn't been negotiated yet.

listitem.para: The name known to the operating system. (eg. on linux it might be eth0)
The speed of the interface, in megabits/sec.
The duplex state the interface is in. See sg_iface_duplex for permitted values.
the timestamp when the above stats where collected in seconds since epoch

refsect1.title: Bugs
refsect1.para: Getting specific details may require elevated privileges, eg. on Linux the interface speed isn't visible for non-privileged processes.

The compare functions exists rather for backward compatibility than for functionality enhancements. Limited flexibility (e.g. reverse order) and lack of optimizing opportunities for the compiler leads to the recommendation to implement the required compare routines locally.
